title: Gỏi Cuốn Plate (Fresh Spring Rolls)
description: Light Vietnamese-style fresh spring rolls filled with tender poached shrimp, crisp herbs, rice vermicelli and crunchy vegetables, served with a savory hoisin-peanut dipping sauce. No frying — gentle poaching and careful rolling preserve bright, herbal flavors and fresh textures.

ingredients.display_name: raw medium shrimp, peeled and deveined (16-20 count), tails removed
ingredients.notes: poach until just cooked; about 2 minutes in simmering water
soak/cook according to package until tender, then rinse cold

ingredients.display_name: butter lettuce leaves, washed and whole
ingredients.notes: use small leaves to line inside wrapper for crunch and barrier from wet filling
use leaves for bright herb flavor
smooth or chunky depending on texture preference
adjust to reach desired dipping consistency
use regular soy sauce (contains gluten); swap tamari for gluten-free
for seasoning poaching water if desired

steps.text: Bring a medium saucepan of water to a gentle simmer and add a pinch of salt; poach the peeled, deveined shrimp in batches until just opaque and cooked through, about 2 minutes per batch. Immediately transfer shrimp to an ice bath to stop cooking, then slice each shrimp in half lengthwise for easier rolling.
Prepare rice vermicelli according to package instructions: soak or cook until tender (typically 3–5 minutes), drain, rinse thoroughly under cold water, and drain again to remove excess moisture.
Julienne carrots and cucumber to thin matchsticks, wash and dry herbs and lettuce. Arrange all fillings on a workstation within reach of the rice paper soaking bowl.

Make the dipping sauce by whisking together hoisin, peanut butter, soy sauce, lime juice, minced garlic, water to thin, and optional chili and sesame oil until smooth; adjust seasoning and consistency to taste and garnish with crushed peanuts.

Fill a large shallow bowl with warm water. Dip one rice paper wrapper into the water for about 6–8 seconds until the surface softens but the wrapper is still slightly firm (it will continue to soften on the board). Lay it flat on a damp cutting board.

Layer a lettuce leaf near the edge closest to you, then a small handful of vermicelli, a few carrot and cucumber matchsticks, and 2–3 herb leaves. Place 3–4 halved poached shrimp, cut side down, near the top edge so shrimp show through the wrapper when rolled.

Fold the bottom edge of the wrapper over the filling, tuck in tightly, fold both sides inward, then roll forward to close into a neat cylinder. Repeat to make remaining rolls, covering finished rolls with a damp towel to prevent drying.

Slice rolls in half on the bias for serving if desired, arrange on a plate with dipping sauce on the side, and serve immediately. Leftover rolls are best eaten within a few hours; store covered in the fridge.
